awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Topographic Controls on Antarctic Ice Sheet Grounding Line Behavior - Integrating Models and Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
Current ice mass loss in Antarctica is largely driven by changes at glacier grounding lines, where inland ice transitions from being grounded to floating in the ocean. The rate and pattern of glacier retreat in these circumstances is thought to be controlled by the terrain under the ice. This project incorporates evidence of past ice-retreat events and other field data, such as grounding-line positions and dates, subglacial topography, and meltwater features, into numerical models of ice flow to investigate the influence that grounding-line processes and subglacial topography have on glacier retreat rates over the past 15,000 years.

Recent observations suggest that Antarctic ice mass loss is largely driven by perturbations at or near the grounding line. However, the lack of information on subglacial and grounding-line environments causes large uncertainties in projections of mass loss and sea-level rise. This project will integrate geologic data from the deglaciated continental shelf into numerical models of varying complexity from one to three-dimensions. Rarely do numerical ice-sheet models of Antarctica have multiple constraints on dynamics over the past ~15,000 years (a period that spans the deglaciation of the Antarctic continental shelf since the Last Glacial Maximum).  The geologic constraints include grounding-line positions, deglacial chronologies, and information on grounding line-ice shelf processes.   The models will be used to investigate necessary perturbations and controls that meet the geological constraints. The multidisciplinary approach of merging geologic reconstructions of paleo-ice behavior with numerical models of ice response will allow the research team to test understanding of subglacial controls on grounding-line dynamics and assess the stability of modern grounding lines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The sensitivity of outlet glaciers to stochastic and climate variability is largely dictated by geometric properties at their grounding lines. Particularly vulnerable are glaciers with smooth beds, reverse bed slopes, and no topographic ‘bumps’ to slow down retreat. In this collaborative project, we merge empirical observations of grounding line properties – from remote sensing of modern grounding lines and geomorphology from the deglaciated Antarctic continental shelf – with a numerical flowline model.

Our model is the first to couple ice sheet dynamics with the transient development of grounding zone wedges. Key results highlight the importance of sedimentation mechanism – namely, whether sediment accumulates in a grounding zone wedge through sediment deformation or by melting out from basal ice. The main difference between these two mechanisms is where the sediment accumulates. As a result, a lower sediment flux is needed to slowdown glacier retreat in the deformation model (which deposits sediment right at the grounding line) as opposed to the melt-out model (which deposits sediment in front of the grounding line).

Along the Pine Island and Thwaites glacier flowline are several small grounding zone wedges with amplitudes of several meters. In our model, these small grounding zone wedges have a weak effect on overall retreat, which was likely initiated by sea level perturbations. When bedslope is relatively flat, stochastic fluctuations in forcings can be enough to allow periodic high sedimentation rates to slow or stop retreat. When retreat continues into deeper water, the impact of these stochastic fluctuations is negligible.

Most modern grounding lines reside on flat and smooth beds with ice that is close to flotation. While glaciers with these characteristics are generally considered most sensitive to climate perturbations, our model results suggest that retreat is ‘easier’ to slowdown in these scenarios. One of our key findings is that observed grounding zone wedges reflect a spectrum of feedbacks with ice dynamics that depend heavily on scale.
